(\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f. = 0/ \u2212 2)\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$169.6\\pm ^{15.9}_{0.1}, 0.48\\pm ^{0.02}_{0.06}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.24\\pm ^{0.34}_{0.19}$|\u2060</span>, [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$-3.8\\pm ^{4.0}_{0.6}$|</span>]\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$63.8\\pm ^{14.2}_{2.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.28\\pm ^{0.16}_{0.06}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN006\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN006\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">All external shears \u03b3 are considered at the position of galaxy G1. For each model, the first (second) line on the third and fourth columns refers to the parameters of G1 (G2); also, the first (second) line on the sixth and eighth columns refers to AB (AC) and <em>F</em><sub>B</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>A</sub> (<em>F</em><sub>C</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>A</sub>), respectively. The position angle is positive from north towards east. Values inside square brackets are constrained with a Gaussian prior given by the observed uncertainties. Unless otherwise specified, all models have (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/\u03bd = 0/0). \u03c3 represents the velocity dispersion of the singular isothermal mass model, \u03b8<sub>E</sub> is the Einstein radius, <em>e</em> is the ellipticity, \u0394<em>t</em> is the time delay and \u03bc represents the total magnification factor; \u03b4 and \u03b3<sup>\u2032</sup> represent the third-order perturbation to the potential and the logarithmic density slope, respectively. The error bars were determined using the Markov chain Monte Carlo method implemented in <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span>, where multiple chains were checked for convergence based on the method described in Gelman et al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>). External convergence from the environment is not considered in the models.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92031889\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92031890 id=\"92031890\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>A third quasar image or an additional galaxy?</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As we have shown above, GX is consistent with the position of a third lensed quasar image. Morphological modelling in the <em>H</em> and <em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup> bands cannot distinguish conclusively between a point-source and an extended morphology. Furthermore, G2 has an estimated Einstein radius of \u223c 0.45\u2009arcsec (Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>), assuming that it is located at the redshift of G1, and the separation between G2 and G3 is only \u223c 0.26\u2009arcsec. Since the colours of GX (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) would put it at <em>z</em> &gt; 1, in the background of G2, it would be strongly lensed. In fact, four or five images of GX would be produced, some of them brighter and at a larger separation from G2. Such a case is clearly inconsistent with the data.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In view of the above, we discuss the possibility of GX being a quasar image, based on its colours. Although the colours are not consistent with those of images A and B, chromatic differences between quasar images are common in the literature (e.g. Falco et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; \u00c9l\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Yonehara et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Such chromatic effects can be caused by dust extinction and microlensing in the lensing galaxy, as well as the intrinsic, time-delayed variability of the source quasar. It is clear that, assuming that GX has a point-like morphology, according to Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, it must be reddened in comparison to A and B. Here we test whether this can be explained by dust extinction. We assume that neither image A nor B is affected by extinction, since their colours are very similar. The colour difference between A and GX (hereafter renamed image C, when referring to its flux/colours), assumed to be due to extinction, can be used to estimate the extinction, using the equation <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\nm_{{\\rm C},i}-m_{{\\rm A},i} = -2.5\\log {F_{\\rm C}/F_{\\rm A}}+A_{\\lambda ,i}\\ \\,.\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div> Here, the left-hand side is the observed magnitude difference of the two images and <em>i</em> refers to each of the three observed bands, <em>JHK</em><sup>\u2032</sup>. <em>F</em> denotes the model-predicted image flux and <em>A</em><sub>\u03bb</sub> is the extinction in the lensing galaxy rest frame; therefore, \u03bb = \u03bb<sub>obs</sub>/(1 + <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>).</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To estimate <em>F</em><sub>C</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>A</sub>, we use the lensing models from Section 5.1, which predict <em>F</em><sub>C</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>A</sub> \u223c 0.25 (ignoring those with large mass ellipticity). The equation can therefore be solved for <em>A</em><sub>\u03bb, <em>i</em></sub>, obtaining a value of \u223c2.1 (<em>J</em>), \u223c1.2 (<em>H</em>) and \u223c0.9 (<em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup>). Using an extinction curve from Cardelli, Clayton &amp; Mathis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>), and an <em>R</em><sub>V</sub> extinction parameter with the Galactic value of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {R}_\\mathrm{V}=3.1$|</span> (in agreement with the value found from the sample of \u00c9l\u00edasd\u00f3ttir), a visual extinction <em>A</em><sub>V</sub> \u223c 2.9 (<em>J</em>), <em>A</em><sub>V</sub> \u223c 2.8 (<em>H</em>) and <em>A</em><sub>V</sub> \u223c 3.1 (<em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup>) is obtained, which translates to <em>E</em>(<em>B</em> \u2212 <em>V</em>) = <em>A</em><sub>V</sub>/<em>R</em><sub>V</sub> \u223c 0.9. Although rare, such large visual extinction and colour excess have been observed in lensing galaxies before (e.g. \u00c9l\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Ostman, Goobar &amp; Mortsell <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). We therefore conclude that colour change due to extinction is plausible. A problem with this interpretation however is why image B, located similarly close to the larger G1, also a similar elliptical galaxy, is not similarly affected by extinction.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An alternative explanation is provided by microlensing due to stars in G2, which can also cause large colour differences (e.g. Yonehara et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). The small separation between G2 and GX (\u223c1 effective radius) makes both extinction and microlensing plausible. If GX is the third quasar image, it has a negative parity, and is therefore more sensitive to microlensing effects (e.g. Schechter &amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). Microlensing is also expected to produce a flux change that is decreasing with wavelength, as observed. Since neither a spectrum of GX (which would also convincingly show whether it is the third quasar image) nor multi-epoch observations in the same band are available, the relative effects of extinction and microlensing cannot be distinguished using the current data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">On the other hand, intrinsic variability is not expected to play a significant part, since it generally produces much smaller colour differences than observed here (e.g. Yonehara et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), and in addition the similar time delays expected between images B and C (Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>) would mean that differences should also be seen between A and B. Lastly, we also investigated whether GX is a chance superposition of a nearby star. Such a case is however excluded due to the observed colours, which are inconsistent with any stars observed in the infrared (Ducati et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92031896 id=\"92031896\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>More quasar images or a quasar host detection?</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">From Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, it is immediately apparent that the source is located very close to a caustic (red curve). As the source crosses inside the caustic, two additional images are created. These images will be located close to, and on each side of the critical line (blue curve). Therefore, it is perhaps not coincidental that the observed elongated galaxy GY is located close to the position where the two additional images are predicted to be. Since morphologically GYb is not consistent with a point source, but only GYa and GYc (although this is not certain, due to the low S/N), the case when GYa and GYc are two additional quasar images was considered. However, this possibility is ruled out because the position of these two objects cannot be reproduced, and in addition they are predicted to be brighter than image A. More specifically, two cases were considered, with or without accounting for GYc as an additional SIS perturber (3SIS+\u03b3 and 2SIS+\u03b3, respectively), and only the positions of the five images were fitted. This resulted in \u03c7<sup>2</sup> \u223c 1400 for 3 and 4 d.o.f., respectively.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There is, however, another interpretation for GY. Its photometric redshift suggests that it may be associated with the quasar. As an isolated galaxy at high redshift, it would be lensed by G1 and G2 into multiple images, a fact which is ruled out by the observed data. It could, however, be interpreted as the quasar host galaxy. In fact, as the source is very close to the caustic and the host galaxy is an extended object, a portion of the host galaxy can cross the caustic and be significantly magnified, whereas the point-like quasar does not. Indeed, Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows that an extended circular source centred on the source quasar would be lensed into an elongated object whose position, elongation and orientation show remarkable agreement with GY.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To test this interpretation, we modelled the source as a superposition of a point-like and an extended (elliptical) S\u00e9rsic profile, and fitted it to the observed data, using <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span>. We used the <em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup> band, where GY is detected at larger S/N, and we modelled the PSF with two concentric Moffat profiles. The reason why the hybrid PSF considered in Section 3.2 is not used is that, through the way it was constructed, it already includes a contribution from the extended source, which cannot be modelled in this case as a different component. We kept fixed the mass model parameters determined from fitting the astrometry and flux ratio constraints in Section 5.1, and varied only the parameters of the PSF and the extended source. Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> depicts the result, which shows that the overall flux of GY is indeed well reproduced by the models, in the case of two as well as three observed quasar images. This profile modelling therefore cannot solve the issue of the number of point-like images that are observed, given the current observational data. Faint features are still visible at the peaks of GYa, GYb and GYc, which are not accounted for with this parametric-based source modelling. We computed the total magnification of the extended source models as the flux ratio in the image plane and source plane, and found a model-dependent value of \u223c 6-11. We also computed the magnification of the modelled GY profile as the ratio of the flux in GY, where all other images were masked, and the region of the source which is mapped into GY (located inside the intersection area of all the caustics shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). Here we found a magnification factor of \u223c 15-20. The magnification of GY relative to the whole unlensed source is \u223c 2-4.</p>                        <a id=\"92031900\" scrollto-destination=\"92031900\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=xJhG7srncLVwyvOEgt~XrxjDk0qqjDMY9ByeVsqxyu32PfrDLDQI92KAbEgDiBHth0aivHqLY44r93hnkO4hTPcveuZTIc06R7fYRzvnVuL1E5sq2JeCCRptMUaKUaxPwZuXXFsOJBQtwioWOZ7J7aRdsNe2OJ8WfwxF1U97IS55uUepsfSC574hNVWRq2cP8YiUY5lITg52DMRbx3qUGZWwjB7jnYocipCav-LxpICTqw-Yj84sFWtM3kTNFoM4zq32UkpyFqhHBJYYsWLeG3--eUk1Jq2rJGA6-S7nSHlkUDOVcty2l1Y~lJqV6zSMunrnjFQPrfkWPuT-jIQj3Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fitting of GY as a lensed feature in the K\u2032 band. Left: all objects have been fitted and subtracted with glafic, using an analytical PSF, and without fitting a quasar host galaxy. Centre and right: a quasar host galaxy modelled as a lensed S\u00e9rsic profile is also fitted, in the cases when either two or three quasar images are observed, successfully removing most of the flux in GY. Objects G2 and GX, in close proximity to each other, are masked, as the three-image lensing model cannot reproduce the flux of GX.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92031900/stu621fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92031900\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/stu621fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&Signature=16D6cTAPrqm2p3HwmIpB5YGhnPCwvFcnbQP0UCx5cBnmtt8CEmg4vaEvdIiBYm35femMj~UB~LsDvl-HwCvJt8ihbz5LIGnv4ebP0qi59yI33yCSeKnvlGP~nSglJpChtJcEy9cqhjepLGs0uDtDU1XVxXt3HlQ1tZDgNnUHgRqz8LDC3Gnq2fY7wD5kVYtzeMkFRKCqQtglwlzsz6CETER8KRNVecL~CIgEuapvclgYWIWDjjKyETv-fq9EVez~J24~3LWrVqTSlK4vjvcst5cKjnbpddIvGvXTmtf0HT-xSusXuXVPWR098ZZJWvcNBwu7b9S247izWSQG2U2Ihw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92031900&ar=1063465&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fitting of GY as a lensed feature in the <em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup> band. Left: all objects have been fitted and subtracted with <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span>, using an analytical PSF, and without fitting a quasar host galaxy. Centre and right: a quasar host galaxy modelled as a lensed S\u00e9rsic profile is also fitted, in the cases when either two or three quasar images are observed, successfully removing most of the flux in GY. Objects G2 and GX, in close proximity to each other, are masked, as the three-image lensing model cannot reproduce the flux of GX.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=xJhG7srncLVwyvOEgt~XrxjDk0qqjDMY9ByeVsqxyu32PfrDLDQI92KAbEgDiBHth0aivHqLY44r93hnkO4hTPcveuZTIc06R7fYRzvnVuL1E5sq2JeCCRptMUaKUaxPwZuXXFsOJBQtwioWOZ7J7aRdsNe2OJ8WfwxF1U97IS55uUepsfSC574hNVWRq2cP8YiUY5lITg52DMRbx3qUGZWwjB7jnYocipCav-LxpICTqw-Yj84sFWtM3kTNFoM4zq32UkpyFqhHBJYYsWLeG3--eUk1Jq2rJGA6-S7nSHlkUDOVcty2l1Y~lJqV6zSMunrnjFQPrfkWPuT-jIQj3Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fitting of GY as a lensed feature in the K\u2032 band. Left: all objects have been fitted and subtracted with glafic, using an analytical PSF, and without fitting a quasar host galaxy. Centre and right: a quasar host galaxy modelled as a lensed S\u00e9rsic profile is also fitted, in the cases when either two or three quasar images are observed, successfully removing most of the flux in GY. Objects G2 and GX, in close proximity to each other, are masked, as the three-image lensing model cannot reproduce the flux of GX.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92031900/stu621fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92031900\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/stu621fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&Signature=16D6cTAPrqm2p3HwmIpB5YGhnPCwvFcnbQP0UCx5cBnmtt8CEmg4vaEvdIiBYm35femMj~UB~LsDvl-HwCvJt8ihbz5LIGnv4ebP0qi59yI33yCSeKnvlGP~nSglJpChtJcEy9cqhjepLGs0uDtDU1XVxXt3HlQ1tZDgNnUHgRqz8LDC3Gnq2fY7wD5kVYtzeMkFRKCqQtglwlzsz6CETER8KRNVecL~CIgEuapvclgYWIWDjjKyETv-fq9EVez~J24~3LWrVqTSlK4vjvcst5cKjnbpddIvGvXTmtf0HT-xSusXuXVPWR098ZZJWvcNBwu7b9S247izWSQG2U2Ihw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92031900&ar=1063465&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fitting of GY as a lensed feature in the <em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup> band. Left: all objects have been fitted and subtracted with <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span>, using an analytical PSF, and without fitting a quasar host galaxy. Centre and right: a quasar host galaxy modelled as a lensed S\u00e9rsic profile is also fitted, in the cases when either two or three quasar images are observed, successfully removing most of the flux in GY. Objects G2 and GX, in close proximity to each other, are masked, as the three-image lensing model cannot reproduce the flux of GX.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The analysis above shows that the data are fully consistent with GY being the quasar host galaxy, lensed into an elongated arc. A question that arises with this interpretation is why GY consists of three components. This might be due to luminous substructure in the host galaxy, irregular overall morphology, a merging system or small perturbers in the lens plane, which might disturb the arc. In particular, since GYa and GYb are on each side of the critical line, it is plausible that they are mirror-symmetric images of the same feature. This was successfully checked by using one of the mass models predicting three quasar images, and considering a second point-like source to be lensed into GYa and GYb (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>). The use of a second source sets tighter constraints on the mass model (models 6 and 7 in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). Three additional images are predicted, and their non-detection can presumably be explained by their close proximity to the quasar images, and their expected small fluxes. The two sources are separated by \u223c 0.22\u2009arcsec in the source plane, or \u223c2 kpc. This is of the order of one effective radius for typical galaxies at the source redshift (e.g. Trujillo et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). We also tried to fit two sources to the mass models predicting two quasar images, but this produced poor fits, with large lens ellipticity for G1 and G2, at vastly different orientations than the observed light profiles.</p>                        <a id=\"92031902\" scrollto-destination=\"92031902\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=JJZIZCftV81Z0IIGRCiC~QapTu7j9ZxG-BTEpxn2ey4pnNQAVA4O0MC3U2FQfN~5T0ALVD8Ypr3Ju6h1o-iwcGRTccYh~mAgkoxdu6lD41A2No8y0TNpwjxTiaQY-0Ys0dPm6BjYVCbaNNMPr0Ykk~R17FjOqQeo7uF384GbRFUhFTlevXfxmU~qn45l5jANh5zI3DDAsScKLKcLx4-20kTidhjZcaJ-Cxn3xgZmtRHJY3JcFTazn2bjm5lhiOQFSBvVqhi2CN3krvE4M6nzeWsKFYmErj2VXNHHFinXHdu36~NsNv1K2suC1A3q~1P7UU4vocxXPsMm8BLNP1KVCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass modelling with two sources, simultaneously reproducing A, B, GX as quasar images, and GYa, GYb as part of a multiply lensed (five image) substructure in the quasar host galaxy. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92031902/stu621fig8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92031902\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/stu621fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&Signature=ndY5iR9P0WINOJ0x3EX-HzjRpFyxWv~TrTytzCJ~-1Jj3gL3B0uWP3W9IgT4fnghMuYffof2RpKEUHwpVNJUOywtvuDPBJ7H5RPwTJVO3Hd3S~tDc3Pc4DLkORxoXp3Ykn-oPjM1WV8WT9YToYnLFfnJhFrlJdB6yoEUitUEoRzuwswL8lzn0pBDOPk6sRAvnO5r9MHYiFwCU3K1is7daI4oP4~76AeDs~yO3t17im3WYV8lXtql1PqQBkh8C08WlOmsQYwhlOkK8zoLxbLjAuzoj3rflncOlQHHvFr~d3uvDg8plNRDsRu6X9xH2iYOjI4fJ9P2dXvnSnn~XItrNw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92031902&ar=1063465&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass modelling with two sources, simultaneously reproducing A, B, GX as quasar images, and GYa, GYb as part of a multiply lensed (five image) substructure in the quasar host galaxy. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=JJZIZCftV81Z0IIGRCiC~QapTu7j9ZxG-BTEpxn2ey4pnNQAVA4O0MC3U2FQfN~5T0ALVD8Ypr3Ju6h1o-iwcGRTccYh~mAgkoxdu6lD41A2No8y0TNpwjxTiaQY-0Ys0dPm6BjYVCbaNNMPr0Ykk~R17FjOqQeo7uF384GbRFUhFTlevXfxmU~qn45l5jANh5zI3DDAsScKLKcLx4-20kTidhjZcaJ-Cxn3xgZmtRHJY3JcFTazn2bjm5lhiOQFSBvVqhi2CN3krvE4M6nzeWsKFYmErj2VXNHHFinXHdu36~NsNv1K2suC1A3q~1P7UU4vocxXPsMm8BLNP1KVCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass modelling with two sources, simultaneously reproducing A, B, GX as quasar images, and GYa, GYb as part of a multiply lensed (five image) substructure in the quasar host galaxy. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92031902/stu621fig8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92031902\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/stu621fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&Signature=ndY5iR9P0WINOJ0x3EX-HzjRpFyxWv~TrTytzCJ~-1Jj3gL3B0uWP3W9IgT4fnghMuYffof2RpKEUHwpVNJUOywtvuDPBJ7H5RPwTJVO3Hd3S~tDc3Pc4DLkORxoXp3Ykn-oPjM1WV8WT9YToYnLFfnJhFrlJdB6yoEUitUEoRzuwswL8lzn0pBDOPk6sRAvnO5r9MHYiFwCU3K1is7daI4oP4~76AeDs~yO3t17im3WYV8lXtql1PqQBkh8C08WlOmsQYwhlOkK8zoLxbLjAuzoj3rflncOlQHHvFr~d3uvDg8plNRDsRu6X9xH2iYOjI4fJ9P2dXvnSnn~XItrNw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92031902&ar=1063465&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass modelling with two sources, simultaneously reproducing A, B, GX as quasar images, and GYa, GYb as part of a multiply lensed (five image) substructure in the quasar host galaxy. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In conclusion, in view of the photometric redshifts, as well as the good overall fit with the flux distribution expected for an extended source crossing a caustic, the data imply that GY indeed represents part of the quasar host galaxy. We refrain however from making quantitative estimates of the physical properties of the host galaxy from the current data. This is because of the quasar image number (and therefore the magnification factor) being unconfirmed, the fragmentation of GY, not accurately reproduced by a single analytical source profile, and the fact that it is difficult to assess whether the analytical PSF is reliably disentangled from, or biases the parameters of the extended source.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92031904 id=\"92031904\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>DISCUSSION, CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORKS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have conducted high-resolution, near-infrared, multiband AO observations with the Subaru Telescope of the gravitationally lensed quasar SDSS J1405+0959. Despite the low Strehl ratios, the observations were successful in uncovering unprecedented detail in this system, and in particular in discovering two new components named GX and GY. We used a new technique to derive the PSF, and determine the morphology, astrometry and photometry of the individual components that constitute the observed system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We showed that GX is likely to be the third quasar image in this system, based on its colours as well as lens modelling. If confirmed, it will be the first small-separation three-image lensed quasar produced by a pair of lensing galaxies, and in addition will allow the study of the interstellar medium of G2. The nature of GX may be tested via high-spatial resolution spectroscopy, or alternatively via deep observations with the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>), which produces a better characterized PSF, and may distinguish between the point-source and extended morphology of GX. In addition, such observations would also better separate the extended quasar host emission from the point-like quasar source. We note that our technique to obtain the PSF may be affected by faint host emission underneath the bright quasar image. This might be responsible for some of the discrepancies in the morphology of G1 and G2 in the three observed bands, since the host galaxy is more prominent at longer wavelengths.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also showed that GY consists of additional lensed images of an extended region of the quasar host galaxy, based on the observed colours and the match between the observed light distribution and that expected for an extended lensed source, given the best available lensing models. AO-assisted or <em>HST</em> spectroscopy to determine a redshift would unambiguously confirm the nature of GY, as well as allow us to study its physical properties, such as star formation. The added advantage here is that GY shows emission from the quasar host galaxy alone which is free of contamination from the bright quasar components. Deeper AO observations, to increase the S/N of GY, would provide hundreds of intensity pixels to further study the mass distribution (e.g. Suyu et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) in this two-galaxy lens system. This would allow a non-parametric reconstruction of the quasar host galaxy in the source plane, which would be helpful to explain the fragmentation observed in GY and, for example, to study the correlation with the supermassive black hole (e.g. Peng et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As an analogy, the known system most similar to SDSS J1405+0959 is MG 2016+112, which also contains an observed arc without a central quasar image. That system also requires two lens galaxies to model, although the second lens is comparatively much weaker, with Einstein radius ratio G1/D \u223c0.11 (following the notations in the literature), whereas for SDSS J1405+0959, G2/G1 \u223c0.55. As such, the tangential caustics in SDSS J1405+0959 merge and the two radial caustics overlap, whereas this does not occur in the case of MG 2016+112, which only produces two quasar images. The latter system however contains much more astrometric constraints, as radio observations (More et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) reveal mirror-symmetric subimages in both quasar images, as well as in the extended arc. On the other hand, SDSS J1405+0959 is radio quiet, based on non-detection in existing radio surveys.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work was supported in part by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) KAKENHI Grant Number 26800093 and World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI Initiative), Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT), Japan. CER acknowledges the support of the JSPS Research Fellowship.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors would like to thank Sherry Suyu for helpful discussions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this superb mountain.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">\u2605</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Based on data collected at Subaru Telescope, which is operated by the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">UKIRT Infrared Deep Sky Survey, Lawrence et al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25a\" data-open=\"bib25a\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> is distributed by the National Optical Astronomy Observatory, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy (AURA) under cooperative agreement with the National Science Foundation.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The package is available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.naoj.org/Observing/DataReduction/index.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.naoj.org/Observing/DataReduction/index.html</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Affix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {1}$|</span> refers to the core, and affix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {2}$|</span> refers to the wings, both modelled as Moffat profiles. Here <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {{\\rm FWHM}}$|</span> (arcsec), <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {e}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {{\\rm PA}}$|</span> (deg) and \u03b2 are the profile full width at half-maximum, ellipticity, position angle (positive from north towards east) and \u03b2 parameter, respectively. The Strehl ratios were computed by comparing the peak flux of the PSF with that of a diffraction-limited PSF model. Due to the low values, these may be insecure.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" For each model, the first (second) line on the third and fourth columns refers to the parameters of G1 (G2); also, the first (second) line on the sixth and eighth columns refers to AB (AC) and <em>F</em><sub>B</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>A</sub> (<em>F</em><sub>C</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>A</sub>), respectively. The position angle is positive from north towards east. Values inside square brackets are constrained with a Gaussian prior given by the observed uncertainties. Unless otherwise specified, all models have (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/\u03bd = 0/0). \u03c3 represents the velocity dispersion of the singular isothermal mass model, \u03b8<sub>E</sub> is the Einstein radius, <em>e</em> is the ellipticity, \u0394<em>t</em> is the time delay and \u03bc represents the total magnification factor; \u03b4 and \u03b3<sup>\u2032</sup> represent the third-order perturbation to the potential and the logarithmic density slope, respectively. The error bars were determined using the Markov chain Monte Carlo method implemented in <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span>, where multiple chains were checked for convergence based on the method described in Gelman et al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span>1995). External convergence from the environment is not considered in the models.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl7\" data-id=\"tbl7\"><span class=\"label\">Table 7.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing models.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Model<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Images<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3, \u03b8<sub>E</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>e</em>, \u03b8<sub>e</sub> (deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b3, \u03b8<sub>\u03b3</sub> (deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394<em>t</em> (d)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03bc<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Flux ratio<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. For each model, the first (second) line on the third and fourth columns refers to the parameters of G1 (G2); also, the first (second) line on the sixth and eighth columns refers to AB (AC) and <em>F</em><sub>B</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>A</sub> (<em>F</em><sub>C</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>A</sub>), respectively. The position angle is positive from north towards east. Values inside square brackets are constrained with a Gaussian prior given by the observed uncertainties. Unless otherwise specified, all models have (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/\u03bd = 0/0). \u03c3 represents the velocity dispersion of the singular isothermal mass model, \u03b8<sub>E</sub> is the Einstein radius, <em>e</em> is the ellipticity, \u0394<em>t</em> is the time delay and \u03bc represents the total magnification factor; \u03b4 and \u03b3<sup>\u2032</sup> represent the third-order perturbation to the potential and the logarithmic density slope, respectively. The error bars were determined using the Markov chain Monte Carlo method implemented in <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span>, where multiple chains were checked for convergence based on the method described in Gelman et al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span>1995). External convergence from the environment is not considered in the models.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div> \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    <div 0.009\u00a0</td><td>Point-like/extended\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>GYb\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.134 \u00b1 0.017\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.561 \u00b1 0.033\u00a0</td><td>Point-like/extended\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>GYc\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.400 \u00b1 0.009\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.933 \u00b1 0.008\u00a0</td><td>Point-like/extended\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The positive directions of X and Y are west and north, respectively. The astrometry is computed as the average positions from the <em>HK</em><sup>\u2032</sup> bands, where the precision is significantly better than in the <em>J</em> band. The errors on the average positions of G2, GX, GY, GYa, GYb and GYc are the sample standard deviation from the <em>HK</em><sup>\u2032</sup> bands, and the errors on A, B and G1, which have consistent astrometry between bands, are errors on the mean (assuming Gaussian measurement errors). The astrometry errors do not include a residual geometrical distortion error estimated to be \u223c1.1 mas (Rusu et al., in preparation), but this has been accounted for when calculating the gravitational lensing parameters in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span>7.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"chapter-para\">The positive directions of X and Y are west and north, respectively. The astrometry is computed as the average positions from the <em>HK</em><sup>\u2032</sup> bands, where the precision is significantly better than in the <em>J</em> band. The errors on the average positions of G2, GX, GY, GYa, GYb and GYc are the sample standard deviation from the <em>HK</em><sup>\u2032</sup> bands, and the errors on A, B and G1, which have consistent astrometry between bands, are errors on the mean (assuming Gaussian measurement errors). The astrometry errors do not include a residual geometrical distortion error estimated to be \u223c1.1 mas (Rusu et al., in preparation), but this has been accounted for when calculating the gravitational lensing parameters in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span>7.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div> \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-SiteWideModals widget-instance-SiteWideModals\">\n        <div id=\"revealModal\" class=\"reveal-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <div (<em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup>)\u00a0</td><td>0.81 \u00b1 0.01\u00a0</td><td>\u221223.8 \u00b1 1.0\u00a0</td><td>0.57 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td><td>0.90 \u00b1 0.13\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN005\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN005\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">All four objects are modelled with S\u00e9rsic profiles. Here <em>e</em> is the ellipticity, <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> is the effective radius measured along the major axis and <em>n</em> is the S\u00e9rsic index. The position angle is positive from north towards east. The morphology of G2 is affected little by whether GX is point-like/extended, the results being consistent at \u223c1\u03c3, whereas the other objects are unaffected by this.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Morphological parameters for SDSS J1405+0959.</p></div> \u00b1 2.1\u00a0</td><td>0.64 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>0.60 \u00b1 0.24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>GY (<em>H</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.81 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td><td>\u221225.2 \u00b1 1.1\u00a0</td><td>0.59 0.03\u00a0</td><td>0.90 \u00b1 0.13\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN005\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN005\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">All four objects are modelled with S\u00e9rsic profiles. Here <em>e</em> is the ellipticity, <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> is the effective radius measured along the major axis and <em>n</em> is the S\u00e9rsic index. The position angle is positive from north towards east. The morphology of G2 is affected little by whether GX is point-like/extended, the results being consistent at \u223c1\u03c3, whereas the other objects are unaffected by this.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" 0.04\u00a0</td><td>Point-like/extended\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">All photometry is model-fitted photometry estimated with <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span>. However, aperture photometry is given for GY, as described in Section 4. Unless written separately, errors on the magnitudes include the scatter between GY being extended/point-like (implemented as S\u00e9rsic profile and PSF, respectively) or GY consisting of one or three components. The errors on the magnitudes of A and B (<em>JK</em><sup>\u2032</sup>) signify systematic offset resulting from the simulations, and were not used for estimating the flux ratio error.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\"       });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            University of class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f444%2f3%2f2561%2f1063465\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\"                      <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92031843 id=\"92031843\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present the result of Subaru Telescope multiband adaptive optics observations of the complex gravitationally lensed quasar SDSS J1405+0959, which is produced by two lensing galaxies. These observations reveal dramatically enhanced morphological detail, leading to the discovery of an additional object 0.26 arcsec from the secondary lensing galaxy, as well as three collinear clumps located in between the two lensing galaxies. The new object is likely to be the third quasar image, although the possibility that it is a galaxy cannot be entirely excluded. If confirmed via future observations, it would be the first three-image lensed quasar produced by two galaxy lenses. In either case, we show based on gravitational lensing models and photometric redshift that the collinear clumps represent merging images of a portion of the quasar host galaxy, with a magnification factor of \u223c 15-20, depending on the model.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;instrumentation adaptive optics&quot;\">instrumentation adaptive optics</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: individual: 14 : 05 :15 . 42 +09 : 59 : 31.3&quot;\">quasars: individual: 14 : 05 :15 . 42 +09 : 59 : 31.3</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92031845 id=\"92031845\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The overwhelming majority of the more than 100 gravitationally lensed quasars known so far consist of two quasar images or, due to the ellipticity of the gravitational potential in the lensing mass, four images. These are galaxy-scale lensed systems, with image separations of \u223c 1\u20132\u2009arcsec, produced by a foreground galaxy acting as a lens. Rarely, small-separation three-image lensed quasars have also been observed (e.g. Lewis et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Winn, Rusin &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), but these contain a central quasar image, close to the centre of a lensing galaxy with a central density profile that is shallower than usual. Ignoring large-separation lensed quasars produced by galaxy clusters (e.g. Oguri et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), another way of producing other than two or four quasar images is found in systems with a group of two (e.g. Shin &amp; Evans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) or three lensing galaxies, with a single confirmed example being the six-image B1359+154 (Rusin et al. 2001). Such systems also offer the chance to study in detail the mass distribution in galaxy pairs from the strong lens modelling of the multiple quasar images, as well as the shape of extended arcs from the quasar host galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An example of a unique lensed quasar in a two-lens system was MG 2016+112 (e.g. Lawrence et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1984</a>; Koopmans et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; More et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), which contains an observed arc that has no optically detected central quasar component, and requires the consideration of both lensing galaxies to explain the observed configuration. Here we show that the recently discovered system SDSS J1405+0959 (Jackson et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Inada et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) is the second example of such a system, and is also likely to be a three-image lensed quasar system. This result is a product of an adaptive optics (AO) imaging campaign of gravitationally lensed quasars (Rusu et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Rusu et al., in preparation) from the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (SQLS; Oguri et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Inada et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Section 2, we summarize the previous observations of this object. In Section 3, we present our AO observations, data reduction and morphological modelling technique. Section 4 addresses the new multiband colour information, and Section 5 presents our gravitational lens mass models. We summarize our conclusions in Section 6. Throughout this work, the concordance cosmology with <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 70\u2009km<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.27 and \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.73 is assumed.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92031849 id=\"92031849\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>PREVIOUSLY AVAILABLE OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J1405+0959 was identified in the SDSS Data Release 7 (Abazajian et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) as a two-component system, one of which is a quasar at <em>z</em> = 1.810. The system was reported by Jackson et al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) as a new gravitationally lensed quasar discovered in the Major UKIDSS<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a>\u2013SDSS Cosmic Lens Survey. This was based on the spectral similarity of the two components, as well as the decrease in separation with increasing wavelength, suggesting the presence of a lensing galaxy. Based on a tentative detection of the 4000 \u00c5 break, as well as possible emission lines, the galaxy redshift was estimated to be <em>z</em> \u223c 0.66.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The system was identified independently as a lensed quasar candidate from the SQLS (see Inada et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), with follow-up spectroscopy and <em>V</em>-, <em>R</em>-, <em>I</em>-band imaging confirming the gravitational lens nature (Inada et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). An additional close-by component, also visible in Jackson et al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), in the infrared, was identified as a potential secondary lens (see Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"92031852\" scrollto-destination=\"92031852\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=V4-j1cvpyhsfd1820ajLIU7zfgDNFUe2KYZJaZBStNUFr5f7quXFKqqNU94heUl-oSv8fvy1ErHcCJXXM3xg41zJVFPyF1bQDg3oGUe5NyL7L8OwUyiVu0oYJ3y0FtRD7LcivEAJl9lwzhfDIOvagQyjl2GXDPnOibisUhiQwRUEFFTs3jkT-AVHmFAnDSidO6DBp9mAjYma6SRE3nAfwsFRYJt0ilkftUVKvysxFtKvfbjduzANXdPqFAmqRyD~BPgNBjeIo3LS6YEfLBJ01QYptkHTga8xvoFDvQWL0stj~j4RneBo6rKE3RHPmYVgrCzboijGYvFx8EyCBvg4Qw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: 5\u2009arcsec \u00d7 5\u2009arcsec JHK\u2032 colour combined close-up of SDSS J1405+0959. The labels correspond to the text. Right: I-band image of the system from the discovery paper (Inada et al. 2014, UH88/8k, 0.235\u2009arcsec pixel scale, 450 s). North is up and east is to the left. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92031852/stu621fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92031852\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/stu621fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&Signature=tM7OjUiXVNA6gwc5~Xuo-j2EqlpsfdCk0tHl4sTszdjaX8ZG8lJOWXn4hgRVcT6nJx~A-ER3fFIGFNTNC9ZXpwDB6Wa1bLlbL5TqYe5uVejpLgGCI22Xspp9QM1~NlUSDzOgaOxOzKp7bQludGv3CAEU1j9r1IkkNsDSCikMNxxa-u271BkptoPGSE6k25LbesabVJxWoiJzKmoO734-oQjtYEnvPiET2fE197z2tIGf~q~rL6TygclcvMfAiayEt-dSJKeh70Zb-7H~hyNsnjj7OxR9elMjqIn~IIKjmQoFENTe1VtIKL~j7CnzM02nnVTi4UxD1-5gPzZzB0dabA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92031852&ar=1063465&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Left: 5\u2009arcsec \u00d7 5\u2009arcsec <em>JHK</em><sup>\u2032</sup> colour combined close-up of SDSS J1405+0959. The labels correspond to the text. Right: <em>I</em>-band image of the system from the discovery paper (Inada et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, UH88/8k, 0.235\u2009arcsec pixel scale, 450 s). North is up and east is to the left. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=V4-j1cvpyhsfd1820ajLIU7zfgDNFUe2KYZJaZBStNUFr5f7quXFKqqNU94heUl-oSv8fvy1ErHcCJXXM3xg41zJVFPyF1bQDg3oGUe5NyL7L8OwUyiVu0oYJ3y0FtRD7LcivEAJl9lwzhfDIOvagQyjl2GXDPnOibisUhiQwRUEFFTs3jkT-AVHmFAnDSidO6DBp9mAjYma6SRE3nAfwsFRYJt0ilkftUVKvysxFtKvfbjduzANXdPqFAmqRyD~BPgNBjeIo3LS6YEfLBJ01QYptkHTga8xvoFDvQWL0stj~j4RneBo6rKE3RHPmYVgrCzboijGYvFx8EyCBvg4Qw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: 5\u2009arcsec \u00d7 5\u2009arcsec JHK\u2032 colour combined close-up of SDSS J1405+0959. The labels correspond to the text. Right: I-band image of the system from the discovery paper (Inada et al. 2014, UH88/8k, 0.235\u2009arcsec pixel scale, 450 s). North is up and east is to the left. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92031852/stu621fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92031852\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/stu621fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&Signature=tM7OjUiXVNA6gwc5~Xuo-j2EqlpsfdCk0tHl4sTszdjaX8ZG8lJOWXn4hgRVcT6nJx~A-ER3fFIGFNTNC9ZXpwDB6Wa1bLlbL5TqYe5uVejpLgGCI22Xspp9QM1~NlUSDzOgaOxOzKp7bQludGv3CAEU1j9r1IkkNsDSCikMNxxa-u271BkptoPGSE6k25LbesabVJxWoiJzKmoO734-oQjtYEnvPiET2fE197z2tIGf~q~rL6TygclcvMfAiayEt-dSJKeh70Zb-7H~hyNsnjj7OxR9elMjqIn~IIKjmQoFENTe1VtIKL~j7CnzM02nnVTi4UxD1-5gPzZzB0dabA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92031852&ar=1063465&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Left: 5\u2009arcsec \u00d7 5\u2009arcsec <em>JHK</em><sup>\u2032</sup> colour combined close-up of SDSS J1405+0959. The labels correspond to the text. Right: <em>I</em>-band image of the system from the discovery paper (Inada et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, UH88/8k, 0.235\u2009arcsec pixel scale, 450 s). North is up and east is to the left. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92031853 id=\"92031853\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>AO OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92031854 id=\"92031854\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>Description of the observations and data reduction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">AO observations were performed with the Infrared Camera and Spectrograph (IRCS; Kobayashi et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) at the Subaru Telescope, in conjunction with the Laser Guide Star AO system (LGS+AO188; Hayano et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Minowa et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). IRCS was used in the 0.0528 arcsec pixel scale mode, providing a field of view (FOV) of 54\u2009arcsec \u00d7 54\u2009arcsec. AO188 employs a curvature wavefront sensor and a 188-element bimorph deformable mirror. The LGS system uses an artificial sodium laser guide star for high-order wavefront sensing (Watanabe et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observations were initially performed in the <em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup> band, followed a year later by the <em>J</em> and <em>H</em> bands, in order to obtain photometric redshifts for the newly detected objects. A summary of the exposure times, observation dates, airmass and photometric standard stars is provided in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92031857\" scrollto-destination=\"92031857\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of observations.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Filter<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Exposure<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Observation<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: 60\u00a0</td><td>2012 February 21\u00a0</td><td>1.10\u20131.14\u00a0</td><td>FS23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>J</em>\u00a0</td><td>19 \u00d7 60\u00a0</td><td>2013 April 27\u00a0</td><td>1.02\u00a0</td><td>FS126\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em>\u00a0</td><td>26 \u00d7 60\u00a0</td><td>2013 April 27\u00a0</td><td>1.02\u20131.07\u00a0</td><td>FS126\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92031857\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of observations.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Filter<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Exposure<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Observation<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Airmass<span aria-hidden=\"true\" aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup>\u00a0</td><td>14 \u00d7 60\u00a0</td><td>2012 February 21\u00a0</td><td>1.10\u20131.14\u00a0</td><td>FS23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>J</em>\u00a0</td><td>19 \u00d7 60\u00a0</td><td>2013 April 27\u00a0</td><td>1.02\u00a0</td><td>FS126\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em>\u00a0</td><td>26 \u00d7 60\u00a0</td><td>2013 April 27\u00a0</td><td>1.02\u20131.07\u00a0</td><td>FS126\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Filter<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Exposure<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Observation<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Airmass<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Photometric<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(s)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>date (UTC)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>standard<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup>\u00a0</td><td>14 \u00d7 60\u00a0</td><td>2012 February 21\u00a0</td><td>1.10\u20131.14\u00a0</td><td>FS23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>J</em>\u00a0</td><td>19 \u00d7 60\u00a0</td><td>2013 April 27\u00a0</td><td>1.02\u00a0</td><td>FS126\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em>\u00a0</td><td>26 \u00d7 60\u00a0</td><td>2013 April 27\u00a0</td><td>1.02\u20131.07\u00a0</td><td>FS126\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92031857\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Even with the use of a laser guide star, a natural bright star is still required in the proximity of the science target, in order to perform low-order, tip-tilt mode wavefront corrections. Such a tip-tilt star was identified well within the recommended brightness limit of <em>R</em> = 18 mag, and inside the recommended separation range of 80\u2009arcsec (Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). In addition, as a bright star does not exist in the SDSS J1405+0959 FOV, a separate star located \u223c 30\u2009arcmin away was observed just after the system (only in the <em>H</em> band), as an independent point spread function (PSF) estimator. This star was selected to have a similar tip-tilt star to that of the system, in terms of brightness and separation (Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"92031859\" scrollto-destination=\"92031859\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table J140517.09+103007.16\u00a0</td><td>Tip-tilt for the PSF star\u00a0</td><td><em>R</em> = 13.1\u00a0</td><td>70.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J140521.31+102933.31\u00a0</td><td>PSF star\u00a0</td><td><em>K</em> = 12.0\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Description<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Magnitude<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: 12.0\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The magnitudes are taken from the Naval Observatory Merged Astrometric Dataset (Zacharias et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) catalogue. \u2018Separation\u2019 specifies the distance between the tip-tilt star and the object, and between the tip-tilt and the PSF star, respectively.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Tip-tilt and PSF stars.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Description<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display:
