13.35\u00a0</td><td>\u223c71.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J140517.09+103007.16\u00a0</td><td>Tip-tilt for the PSF star\u00a0</td><td><em>R</em> = 13.1\u00a0</td><td>70.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J140521.31+102933.31\u00a0</td><td>PSF star\u00a0</td><td><em>K</em> = 12.0\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Description<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Magnitude<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Separation (arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SDSS J140514.96+095820.10\u00a0</td><td>Tip-tilt star\u00a0</td><td><em>R</em> = 13.35\u00a0</td><td>\u223c71.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J140517.09+103007.16\u00a0</td><td>Tip-tilt for the PSF star\u00a0</td><td><em>R</em> = 13.1\u00a0</td><td>70.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J140521.31+102933.31\u00a0</td><td>PSF star\u00a0</td><td><em>K</em> = 12.0\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The magnitudes are taken from the Naval Observatory Merged Astrometric Dataset (Zacharias et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) catalogue. \u2018Separation\u2019 specifies the distance between the tip-tilt star and the object, and between the tip-tilt and the PSF star, respectively.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92031859\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The observations were performed with 8\u2009arcsec dithering, in order to remove bad pixels and cosmic rays, and to allow for the creation of flat frames and sky frames from the data. Data reduction was performed with <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a>, using the IRCS <span class=\"small-caps\">imgred</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a> (Minowa et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) package designed to reduce data obtained with IRCS, and supplemented with a geometrical distortion correction.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometric zero-point calibration was performed using the observed standard stars in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. All objects were corrected for Galactic extinction (Schlegel, Finkbeiner &amp; Davis <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>), and atmospheric extinction relative to the standard star. The standard star catalogue magnitudes at the <em>K</em> band were used to calibrate the photometry at the <em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup> band, since the expected differences based on interpolation<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a> are small (0.01\u20130.03 mag).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92031862 id=\"92031862\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>PSF and morphological modelling</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As seen from Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, the AO observations reveal dramatically increased detail compared to Inada et al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Two new features were identified. First, there is a red object marked GX just to the east of galaxy G2. Secondly, there is a fainter highly elongated object, GY, in between G1 and G2, which seems to be fragmented into three components, the central one being brightest. As the same structure was observed in both the <em>H</em> and <em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup> bands, this fragmentation is real, and not due to low signal-to-noise (S/N).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to characterize the morphology of the individual components of this system, as well as extract relative astrometric and photometric quantities, it is necessary to have an accurate knowledge of the PSF of the system. The PSF is difficult to characterize for most AO observations, as it varies significantly on scales of \u2272 1\u2009arcmin, or the size of the isoplanatic angle. On these scales, the probability of serendipitously finding a bright star on the line of sight to extragalactic sources is very small. In the present case, a single star is found reasonably close to the system, but is significantly fainter than the point-like quasar components. Therefore, as described in Section 3.1, we attempted to characterize the PSF by observing a separate bright star. However, as was noticed in other works (e.g. Kuhlbrodt et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) which have employed this technique, temporal changes in the atmospheric turbulence characteristics induce different response from the AO system, making the use of non-simultaneous PSF estimates problematic. Indeed, using the star as a PSF template has resulted in outstanding residuals when modelling away the point-like components in SDSS J1405+0959. For this reason, we have skipped the separate PSF star observations in the <em>J</em> and <em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup> bands altogether. None the less, we have still made use of the PSF star observations, as will be shown below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since a suitable external PSF estimate is not available, the information provided by the observed system itself must be used in order to estimate the PSF (e.g. Lagattuta, Auger &amp; Fassnacht <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Koptelova et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Oya et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). We adopted a new technique, in which for each of the three-band observations, we started by masking G2, GX and GY, and then we fitted the bright components A, B and G1 simultaneously. Here, A and B consisted of an analytical PSF approximated as two concentric elliptical Moffat profiles, and G1 was the convolution between the analytical PSF and a S\u00e9rsic profile. The best-fitting analytical parameters were obtained through \u03c7<sup>2</sup> minimization, based on the method implemented in <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The resulting first-order PSF was used to fit G2, GX and GY as well, each as a S\u00e9rsic profile, and subtract them. After masking the prominent residuals left under the subtracted objects, the remaining component A was refitted with an analytical PSF. The best-fitting PSF parameter values are given in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. A final hybrid PSF, consisting of a core and a wing component, was then created by keeping the observed distribution of pixel values in a circular region centred around the peak, large enough to include all visible non-analytical residuals, and replacing the distribution at larger radii with the analytical profile. This technique produces a PSF that is cleared of contamination from the nearby objects, includes the non-analytical features that are otherwise not reproduced by an analytical PSF and has a wing that is noise-free. Components A, B, G1, G2, GX and GY were then refitted with <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> (Peng et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) using the new PSF, where the quasar images A and B were fitted as PSFs, and G1 and G2 as S\u00e9rsic profiles, convolved with the PSF. GX was fitted as a PSF and, alternatively, a S\u00e9rsic profile, whereas GY was fitted either as a single S\u00e9rsic profile or as a S\u00e9rsic profile (GYb) and two PSFs (GYa and GYc). The residuals after morphological modelling in the three bands are shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. The extracted astrometry and photometry, as well as the parameters of the extended components, are given in Tables 4\u20136.</p>                        <a id=\"92031866\" scrollto-destination=\"92031866\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=CL8SoIMhlxAfovdxzyXVWZbAYOqbFVHKvc09leMYo3eibPmMADzHQCczamOIu41tFyI4d9Bfa2mvEwTfT~5xQnPtCHveNcO34WKfjAhPBAeHAULasUIBYejX41Zwf0k1QaNnlXIwknb~hWBEsQwRrJlL1tedQ6OzAcaPZfGqt2~ntd8D0133qonirNkirwkEf9aOW6ihrtRz70WkK3g1GSZET71aiBdKc3Q8d0CAuG7QEVCf6DGKmSRNnZV3dRHFpCbxSxdycsHkmd1wCl6rGzrr1ExyrgR0CLBIwafjBeUaYsfLEiY6ayCPQLG8DOYupf-J9ei9aqiTJpxzo6egug__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS J1405+0959 imaging observations in the K\u2032, H and J bands (from top to bottom). (PSF)\u00a0</td><td>0.17\u00a0</td><td>0.09\u00a0</td><td>12.8\u00a0</td><td>43.3\u00a0</td><td>0.46\u00a0</td><td>0.14\u00a0</td><td>\u221242.5\u00a0</td><td>2.3\u00a0</td><td>0.27\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup>\u00a0</td><td>0.18\u00a0</td><td>0.11\u00a0</td><td>27.9\u00a0</td><td>6.3\u00a0</td><td>0.54\u00a0</td><td>0.07\u00a0</td><td>\u221260.4\u00a0</td><td>1.7\u00a0</td><td>0.21\u00a0</td><td>7\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Affix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {1}$|</span> refers to the core, and affix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {2}$|</span> refers to the wings, both modelled as Moffat profiles. Here <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {{\\rm FWHM}}$|</span> (arcsec), <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {e}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {{\\rm PA}}$|</span> (deg) and \u03b2 are the profile full width at half-maximum, ellipticity, position angle (positive from north towards east) and \u03b2 parameter, respectively. The Strehl ratios were computed by comparing the peak flux of the PSF with that of a diffraction-limited PSF model. Due to the low values, these may be insecure.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92031867\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div   .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(flux1 + flux2)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>ratio (per\u2009cent)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>J</em>\u00a0</td><td>0.18\u00a0</td><td>0.07\u00a0</td><td>21.7\u00a0</td><td>6.0\u00a0</td><td>0.55\u00a0</td><td>0.16\u00a0</td><td>\u221275.9\u00a0</td><td>2.5\u00a0</td><td>0.15\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em>\u00a0</td><td>0.17\u00a0</td><td>0.07\u00a0</td><td>\u221248.0\u00a0</td><td>8.3\u00a0</td><td>0.51\u00a0</td><td>0.27\u00a0</td><td>\u221263.2\u00a0</td><td>2.2\u00a0</td><td>0.16\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em> (PSF)\u00a0</td><td>0.17\u00a0</td><td>0.09\u00a0</td><td>12.8\u00a0</td><td>43.3\u00a0</td><td>0.46\u00a0</td><td>0.14\u00a0</td><td>\u221242.5\u00a0</td><td>2.3\u00a0</td><td>0.27\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup>\u00a0</td><td>0.18\u00a0</td><td>0.11\u00a0</td><td>27.9\u00a0</td><td>6.3\u00a0</td><td>0.54\u00a0</td><td>0.07\u00a0</td><td>\u221260.4\u00a0</td><td>1.7\u00a0</td><td>0.21\u00a0</td><td>7\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Affix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {1}$|</span> refers to the core, and affix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {2}$|</span> refers to the wings, both modelled as Moffat profiles. Here <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {{\\rm FWHM}}$|</span> (arcsec), <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {e}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {{\\rm PA}}$|</span> (deg) and \u03b2 are the profile full width at half-maximum, ellipticity, position angle (positive from north towards east) and \u03b2 parameter, respectively. The Strehl ratios were computed by comparing the peak flux of the PSF with that of a diffraction-limited PSF model. Due to the low values, these may be insecure.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92031867\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                        <a id=\"92031868\" scrollto-destination=\"92031868\"></a>\r\n<div class=\"chapter-para\">The positive directions of X and Y are west and north, respectively. The astrometry is computed as the average positions from the <em>HK</em><sup>\u2032</sup> bands, where the precision is significantly better than in the <em>J</em> band. The errors on the average positions of G2, GX, GY, GYa, GYb and GYc are the sample standard deviation from the <em>HK</em><sup>\u2032</sup> bands, and the errors on A, B and G1, which have consistent astrometry between bands, are errors on the mean (assuming Gaussian measurement errors). The astrometry errors do not include a residual geometrical distortion error estimated to be \u223c1.1 mas (Rusu et al., in preparation), but this has been accounted for when calculating the gravitational lensing parameters in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table class=\"chapter-para\">All photometry is model-fitted photometry estimated with <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span>. However, aperture photometry is given for GY, as described in Section 4. Unless written separately, errors on the magnitudes include the scatter between GY being extended/point-like (implemented as S\u00e9rsic profile and PSF, respectively) or GY consisting of one or three components. The errors on the magnitudes of A and B (<em>JK</em><sup>\u2032</sup>) signify systematic offset resulting from the simulations, and were not used for estimating the flux ratio 0.02\u00a0</td><td>41.1 \u00b1 2.7\u00a0</td><td>1.01 \u00b1 0.11\u00a0</td><td>6.30 \u00b1 0.33\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G1 (<em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup>)\u00a0</td><td>0.18 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td><td>43.4 \u00b1 7.6\u00a0</td><td>1.06 \u00b1 0.30\u00a0</td><td>7.49 \u00b1 0.54\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G2 (<em>J</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.49 \u00b1 0.08\u00a0</td><td>\u22126.7 \u00b1 3.0\u00a0</td><td>0.33 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>2.51 \u00b1 0.55\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G2 (<em>H</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.48 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td><td>\u22129.0 \u00b1 1.8\u00a0</td><td>0.32 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>6.06 \u00b1 0.50\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G2 (<em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup>)\u00a0</td><td>0.54 \u00b1 0.07\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.8 \u00b1 2.8\u00a0</td><td>0.25 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td><td>5.46 \u00b1 0.66\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>GY (<em>J</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.80 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td><td>\u221222.1 \u00b1 2.1\u00a0</td><td>0.64 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>0.60 \u00b1 0.24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>GY (<em>H</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.81 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td><td>\u221225.2 \u00b1 1.1\u00a0</td><td>0.59 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>0.76 \u00b1 0.17\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>GY (<em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup>)\u00a0</td><td>0.81 \u00b1 0.01\u00a0</td><td>\u221223.8 \u00b1 1.0\u00a0</td><td>0.57 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td><td>0.90 \u00b1 0.13\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN005\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN005\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">All four objects are modelled with S\u00e9rsic profiles. Here <em>e</em> is the ellipticity, <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> is the effective radius measured along the major axis and <em>n</em> is the S\u00e9rsic index. The position angle is positive from north towards east. The morphology of G2 is affected little by whether GX is point-like/extended, the results being consistent at \u223c1\u03c3, whereas the other objects are unaffected by this.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92031870\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The technique summarized above assumes that the AO PSF does not vary spatially across the components of the system, which is a reasonable assumption given the small maximum separation \u223c 2\u2009arcsec of these components. The use of the two concentric Moffat profiles as an analytical PSF approximation, instead of, for example, a Gaussian representing a diffraction-limited core and a Moffat (Moffat <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1969</a>) for the wing was found to provide a better approximation for the stars observed at low Strehl ratios in the current AO observation campaign (Rusu et al., in preparation). Additional detail about the technique above is presented in Rusu et al. (in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to account for systematics introduced by the technique above, the error bars in Tables 4 \u20136 show the largest error obtained from several methods: individual fitting statistical error resulting from the <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> modelling, scatter from using two different hybrid PSF core radii (10 and 18 pixels), and scatter (where applicable) from GX and GY being fitted as point-source/S\u00e9rsic profile and one/three components, respectively. Finally, the non-simultaneously observed PSF star in the <em>H</em> band was used to simulate the observed system 100 times, where each simulation differs in terms of the added noise, taken from a portion of the observed image that is devoid of sources. Each simulated image was then modelled in a way similar to the technique described above. The errors resulting from these simulations are the standard deviations in the 100 values of each best-fitting parameter around the known true value. These therefore include both systematic and statistical errors, and are typically larger than the errors obtained from the other methods. An implicit assumption in this method is that the observed PSF star can be used as a representation of the actual PSFs in the <em>J</em>, <em>H</em> and <em>K</em><sup>\u2032</sup> bands, albeit solely for the purpose of estimating realistic error bars. This assumption is partly justified by the similarity of the analytical parameters describing the four PSFs in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, in particular FWHM1, <em>e1</em>, FWHM2, the flux ratio and the Strehl ratio.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As overall results, we have determined that the morphology of G1 and G2 is consistent with extended objects (galaxies). However, due to the low S/N and close proximity to G2, it cannot be reliably distinguished whether GX is extended or point-like. In case it is fitted by a S\u00e9rsic profile, it has a small effective radius and an unreliably determined S\u00e9rsic index. On the other hand, GY consists of three features. While the central feature is extended, the morphology of the other two cannot be constrained, and for the purpose of extracting the astrometry, they have been fitted as point sources.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92031874 id=\"92031874\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>PHOTOMETRIC REDSHIFTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Using the new high-resolution observations, photometric redshifts were computed and a colour\u2013colour plot was drawn for the objects seen in the FOV that is shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. The magnitudes of the isolated galaxies were measured with aperture photometry, and those of G1, G2 and GX were obtained from profile fitting. As GY seems to consist of three objects, which all appear to be red in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, and are difficult to model analytically due to the low S/N, aperture photometry was performed assuming that they all have the same colour. For this, all other objects were removed, using the best-fitting model obtained with the hybrid PSF, and the residuals were covered with nearby blank sky. Three different blank sky covers were considered, in order to account for possible systematics. An aperture of 30 pixel radius was chosen for the aperture photometry, centred on GYb. The resulting error bars in all bands are smaller than 0.05 mag.</p>                        <a id=\"92031876\" scrollto-destination=\"92031876\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=DaWKmZ4GYhJjSziJ8vz~LTnAlM6CTEKFsm01stKGpnwuk7deyXxNpduHpOuSuz6ziP9bDBUlD5-sXgtc7PumpZl1Hgk86kXDTrFh6Pkys~lrp8n4w29ib9XXs0KrBuAWJPdY8eGWiAuWwOadwZJ5yYGtGRJGH9LJCUFWw1KAmOKBjGR5bkCg5qDH~3OQkCaNkf2LKy74~oYbPbl1IJayHYJNzdIz4AX-3LpiGe8OstcriByuJCks~Wn1hvYDQDTE8~XRttPLY1Fjo0alxwLFTJ9rghVJmahJcYmVRwAXbSCFe-K1znDNAwuXtiZlZZhzpaSaDM7vtmJIVwmLw82YNQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Environment of SDSS J1405+0959 in the J band. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">According to the colour\u2013colour plot (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), the galaxies seen in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> show various colours, indicative of different redshifts rather than physical association into a group of galaxies. We estimated photometric redshifts from the <em>JHK</em><sup>\u2032</sup> bands using the template-fitting methods implemented in the publicly available software <span class=\"small-caps\">hyperz</span> (Bolzonella, Miralles &amp; Pell\u00f3 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). As templates, we employed the observed mean spectral energy distributions of galaxies from Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"92031878\" scrollto-destination=\"92031878\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=jo6hwQEynmCVIHHLMvOWweDa-FHE3pxPwjWBEikUHN3mHRhhtX4jX8tZOyh10hezRULXKY3sbCwMxBgnz8IZAWog5tvt1hPdw7SVRt4ekuOGTLk3fZblmt7N93Il3I2hG387GsAqxV8Z4zlrRs5rRSMx2am6GK7TZdZzlxuGMd1pm6W7pP0kMY30EsNVO6VkwZvBhVylKM3NOlI99492zlgmWURz6tOtei9uDrVN2qDdowfmqDKQMj9PbVsY3iRbLzdXNUFzYhaZRIYOT0SIZoQVX3OFKv7JDUwTAZHMQZGrlV6ddCmSeV7Q-9cxj2mkKADuAAg22q1tPuc87MSZfg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour\u2013colour plot of galaxies in the SDSS J1405+0959 FOV. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92031878/stu621fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92031878\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/stu621fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&Signature=hXf8jpfKe3J6gm5p7Pzx7aymxK3VaU9jL0U5ARN6LHt0DLwQYdCztMkYAxNneZNcmLYxpyAO-qLt4D2t2wLOFq8xynEaPjqudAdcScOpHjC0TiRmNnokm-3jcWuBj~tmmQAv1WQYRVv2j9mcNmf1khUYEupi36PxyLFMunAvgc7~dw6oEF-T483uWHTDHr-w~21poJYMRztaH7WZ-hzXIZuRyMfrYaPvqMzjXGM~KfatFlvIiHkH5MIv4DARmjLVtIvZyVeggb6y03qSMB-YZnIw~509MB0WaZwk1Hs2ESHi1N7kS-eBAUlHQLey9xpkKfc6VGux45Evd4yhm14OXA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92031878&ar=1063465&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour\u2013colour plot of galaxies in the SDSS J1405+0959 FOV. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=jo6hwQEynmCVIHHLMvOWweDa-FHE3pxPwjWBEikUHN3mHRhhtX4jX8tZOyh10hezRULXKY3sbCwMxBgnz8IZAWog5tvt1hPdw7SVRt4ekuOGTLk3fZblmt7N93Il3I2hG387GsAqxV8Z4zlrRs5rRSMx2am6GK7TZdZzlxuGMd1pm6W7pP0kMY30EsNVO6VkwZvBhVylKM3NOlI99492zlgmWURz6tOtei9uDrVN2qDdowfmqDKQMj9PbVsY3iRbLzdXNUFzYhaZRIYOT0SIZoQVX3OFKv7JDUwTAZHMQZGrlV6ddCmSeV7Q-9cxj2mkKADuAAg22q1tPuc87MSZfg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour\u2013colour plot of galaxies in the SDSS J1405+0959 FOV. Objects that are part of the SDSS J1405+0959 system are marked with red. The labels correspond to those in Fig. 3. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92031878/stu621fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92031878\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/stu621fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&Signature=hXf8jpfKe3J6gm5p7Pzx7aymxK3VaU9jL0U5ARN6LHt0DLwQYdCztMkYAxNneZNcmLYxpyAO-qLt4D2t2wLOFq8xynEaPjqudAdcScOpHjC0TiRmNnokm-3jcWuBj~tmmQAv1WQYRVv2j9mcNmf1khUYEupi36PxyLFMunAvgc7~dw6oEF-T483uWHTDHr-w~21poJYMRztaH7WZ-hzXIZuRyMfrYaPvqMzjXGM~KfatFlvIiHkH5MIv4DARmjLVtIvZyVeggb6y03qSMB-YZnIw~509MB0WaZwk1Hs2ESHi1N7kS-eBAUlHQLey9xpkKfc6VGux45Evd4yhm14OXA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92031878&ar=1063465&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour\u2013colour plot of galaxies in the SDSS J1405+0959 FOV. Objects that are part of the SDSS J1405+0959 system are marked with red. The labels correspond to those in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In particular, G3, G4 and G6 have a redshift probability (G3 is shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) consistent with <em>z</em> \u223c 0.3, which is the estimated redshift of G3 in the SDSS. On the other hand, G1, G2 and G8 have similar colours and redshifts in agreement with <em>z</em> \u223c 0.66, the spectroscopically estimated redshift of G1. GX has different estimated colours in the extended/point-source cases, and assuming that it is a galaxy, it would be located at <em>z</em> &gt; 1. More interestingly, GY appears to have a large redshift, consistent with that of the quasar.</p>                        <a id=\"92031880\" scrollto-destination=\"92031880\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=EBNol4cQ0lol6j5-ntYL1KCCXQF9YfVlbDl7B8VO5C7PJXdy9P7hiN0rsjpPtpHGLWHRbl2nDeDy2JxA3Nq43mRiPkELL26spBbvnNoH8U3ty5VpKYuXVvfTaI8l~odISAqU9MBF7V54TCnfe2BXZswbUkNUgCa7k85OxFDOfWM1CanFmfmqVAoj~Y~Um1-mWRUNw8tw28mt2slfgsS~AbloWHVb~8QePMwiekJ1qMI0TyeDwGWlKkhX9QrY1oX-gdcOVlROUTa~-dgvWFWsPJjdygr3EOF3Z0~4njuXPdgKD0jIxWZWDPQ8g7G67SEnqeKEEwfLiBccKh~KsxUcDA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Photometric redshifts for galaxies in the SDSS J1405+0959 FOV, obtained with hyperz. The vertical axis represents the probability of exceeding the \u03c72 value obtained during the fit by chance, as a function of the number of degrees of freedom (=2). (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92031880/stu621fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92031880\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/stu621fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&Signature=J60Ph5z3K-bFqMgou96ZJPLTxnUtL-Wwee2BQ093CzvojWKjPQhZR0m0ZjnFSmi~Y~nyrc0~caeb7MMTOVaZDtqGKNd5h6oK-CY3u8xghD8a0IMPqcGWcWa-xK0IAQgIbuBrdkiZ-1WOS6oxRke2bR4-DvSBr-7KSqZS37iVBpjns-fHxBdTJbNNhYKi86wabJDXbqysGdAF8A5onUd9LF17DHAQ3ZyzWvwTnXuClT2O2v1Zt4wEkF7qjDQu86mPxPNgDZc3WaD7H1tzsVhHmC-pxPhh8ok5jLhQ5IeatvxkwdgQyE75o5HlDdaBA1CsDjo~8E5l7PVbe8ORO0cZuQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92031880&ar=1063465&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometric redshifts for galaxies in the SDSS J1405+0959 FOV, obtained with <span class=\"small-caps\">hyperz</span>. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=EBNol4cQ0lol6j5-ntYL1KCCXQF9YfVlbDl7B8VO5C7PJXdy9P7hiN0rsjpPtpHGLWHRbl2nDeDy2JxA3Nq43mRiPkELL26spBbvnNoH8U3ty5VpKYuXVvfTaI8l~odISAqU9MBF7V54TCnfe2BXZswbUkNUgCa7k85OxFDOfWM1CanFmfmqVAoj~Y~Um1-mWRUNw8tw28mt2slfgsS~AbloWHVb~8QePMwiekJ1qMI0TyeDwGWlKkhX9QrY1oX-gdcOVlROUTa~-dgvWFWsPJjdygr3EOF3Z0~4njuXPdgKD0jIxWZWDPQ8g7G67SEnqeKEEwfLiBccKh~KsxUcDA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Photometric redshifts for galaxies in the SDSS J1405+0959 FOV, obtained with hyperz. The vertical axis represents the probability of exceeding the \u03c72 value obtained during the fit by chance, as a function of the number of degrees of freedom (=2). (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92031880/stu621fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92031880\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/stu621fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&Signature=J60Ph5z3K-bFqMgou96ZJPLTxnUtL-Wwee2BQ093CzvojWKjPQhZR0m0ZjnFSmi~Y~nyrc0~caeb7MMTOVaZDtqGKNd5h6oK-CY3u8xghD8a0IMPqcGWcWa-xK0IAQgIbuBrdkiZ-1WOS6oxRke2bR4-DvSBr-7KSqZS37iVBpjns-fHxBdTJbNNhYKi86wabJDXbqysGdAF8A5onUd9LF17DHAQ3ZyzWvwTnXuClT2O2v1Zt4wEkF7qjDQu86mPxPNgDZc3WaD7H1tzsVhHmC-pxPhh8ok5jLhQ5IeatvxkwdgQyE75o5HlDdaBA1CsDjo~8E5l7PVbe8ORO0cZuQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92031880&ar=1063465&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometric redshifts for galaxies in the SDSS J1405+0959 FOV, obtained with <span class=\"small-caps\">hyperz</span>. The labels correspond to those in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. The vertical lines mark the spectroscopic redshift of the source quasar and of the main lensing galaxy G1, respectively. The vertical axis represents the probability of exceeding the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> value obtained during the fit by chance, as a function of the number of degrees of freedom (=2). (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92031881 id=\"92031881\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>GRAVITATIONAL LENS MASS MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we test various mass models by exploring different scenarios given the complexity of this system. The most important constraint for strong lensing models is astrometrical. Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> provides high-precision astrometry, as a result of the multiband AO observations. We also used as constraint the flux ratio <em>F</em><sub>A</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>B</sub>, which is very consistent between bands, and also with the optical flux ratio in Inada et al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). An uncertainty of 10 per\u2009cent was set on the observed flux ratio constraint used for the gravitational lens models (Yonehara, Hirashita &amp; Richter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Even in the case of GX being the third quasar image, since its flux is likely to be affected by chromatic processes, we do not use it as a constraint in our model. The singular isothermal profile has extensively been shown to be a good approximation for the mass distribution in lensing galaxies (e.g. Koopmans et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Oguri, Rusu &amp; Falco <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, and references within). We therefore considered a singular isothermal sphere (SIS), or the more general power-law profile <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rho (r)\\propto r^{-\\gamma ^{\\prime }}$|\u2060</span>, as our mass models. We performed all gravitational lens modelling with <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92031883 id=\"92031883\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>Fitting two and three quasar images</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we discuss two mass models (a) assuming that the system consists of only two lensed quasar images A and B, and (b) assuming that the system consists of three lensed images, A, B and GX. The latter case is suggested by the insecure morphology of GX (Section 3.2), as well as the subsequent analysis based on its colours, which we will show in Section 5.2. First, we considered the case when there are only two quasar images. G2 must be taken into account as a lens, due to its small distance to A and B, which is similar to the separation between them, and its similar luminosity to G1. Given the agreement between the photometric redshift of G1 and G2 (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>), we assumed that they are both located at the lens redshift <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 0.66 and that the ratio of their velocity dispersions is constrained from their relative luminosities, through the Faber\u2013Jackson relation (Faber &amp; Jackson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1976</a>). We used the 2SIS+\u03b3 model, where the external shear \u03b3 was considered at the location of G1. We ignored the gravitational lens effect of GX which, assuming it is a galaxy, appears to have different colours and therefore redshift compared to the main deflectors, and is located very close to G2 while being much fainter, making it a comparatively weaker lens. The parameters of this best-fitting model, as well as those described below, are given in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Next, the case when GX is an additional quasar image was considered. Here, the observed position of image GX is an additional observational constraint. No flux ratio constraints were used, but the velocity dispersions of both G1 and G2 were fitted as free parameters. A perfect fit (d.o.f. = 0) was obtained, with the velocity dispersion ratio G2/G1 =0.76, very close to the value obtained from the Faber\u2013Jackson relation (\u223c0.73).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This result shows that it is indeed possible for this two-galaxy system to produce three quasar images at the observed positions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">If an attempt is made to model the observed flux ratio <em>F</em><sub>A</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>B</sub> as well, \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f. = 4.7/1 is obtained. While this is not a very good fit, the model might be oversimplified. Allowing for a third-order perturbation (Bernstein &amp; Fischer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>), a perfect fit is obtained (model 4 in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>), where the orientation of the new component is fixed to correspond with that of the shear, in order to avoid a model with negative number of degrees of freedom. The use of a third-order perturbation may be justified by the presence of the crowded environment in which the system is embedded (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). As a last model, a power-law (G1) + SIS (G2) +\u03b3 profile was also considered, with \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f.\u2009= 0.3/0 (model 8 in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). The reason why this is not a perfect fit is that the source is very close to the caustic, which is a curve in the source plane determined from the observed image, lens configuration and lens profile, whose crossing changes the observed image multiplicity (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). This can be avoided (i.e. the relative position of the source and caustic can be modified) if ellipticity is also introduced, in the form of the singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE), at the expense of having negative degrees of freedom: a power-law + \u03b3 (G1) + SIE (G2) model produces \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f.\u2009= 0/ \u2212 2 (model 9 in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). For all mass models described here, elliptical counterparts were also considered (Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>), where the orientation of the major axis was fixed to the value obtained from morphological fitting (Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>), and the same was done for the ellipticity, unless this cannot reproduce the number of observed images. This approach uses the known correlation between the orientations of mass and light profiles in elliptical lens galaxies (e.g. Keeton, Kochanek &amp; Falco <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Sluse et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), as well as their mass and light ellipticity (Gavazzi et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Sluse et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, but see also Keeton et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Ferreras, Saha &amp; Burles <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Representative lensing models obtained in this section are plotted in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92031888\" scrollto-destination=\"92031888\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=MLXEyr~gt~2N9ONLZA8RE6aHe4Z4jxbCFXo2iQyzgus4hs7N1ZlxZhZ6QMUUN0hlynFmjmv4sWv4-cHfIo3lmJjG2ak3-RLsSJASZN7PJWOPMlVuDgRj1QzECXrigk-E2Vy25l~qJPX41mKgdiGUyNHiL8xRQJKAf7dirdif2jDm-UeW9y9uopHyvnSVGLhDJY4LO~mpJbudcSYG8DeOqmrCSxM-XXv2-tSVOD6KacRikykwtE9E5qjtljklKWLUNxYqf~BH6Ol3-jxpXfec0iDGiIWq6NjNbeRO1m6aVH4h4eAEArUmsUO0DA6j063cgb5y09GZk8MGVwqu0mhhRQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass models for SDSS J1405+0959. The orientation corresponds to that in Fig. 1. Critical lines $\\mathit {({\\rm blue})}$ and caustics $\\mathit {({\\rm red})}$ are shown. The crosses mark the positions of the lensing galaxies, and the triangles the positions of the sources in the source plane. The flux distributions of a lensed circular extended (S\u00e9rsic profile) source are shown. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92031888/stu621fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92031888\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/stu621fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&Signature=jQ5h1YGobtRaOu~aPJfS25DatdBLtWgXrH8-1myrizxY6EueloVO1vg7l-eceU-MTb0AtYQoW5poLYou~jvpY-9mmHDKjTBWKLnMp4ymXfcE7zTcxuIH3fzd1QcOYkc0hWLqYFcJB2x3N8~SpJdaq3WOtROkbLKpN9KTsQazvjhlQTcu-eYY5hTDkWqlGLyZL3tCs3x5kb6zofGvXxmGYp8fxwxvRxL~QECJBq45I5fcgPnAKJ2PiNSVwZgkQylS6jjvY5Kjlg5ZWC6q6gMjCHvMPKyaWbRTUAZk~Tj83YUEU-uviY-MWpnYdOqLjhR9FZIT2qJZGkhNoGxqr~D1vw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92031888&ar=1063465&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass models for SDSS J1405+0959. Critical lines <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {({\\rm blue})}$|</span> and caustics <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {({\\rm red})}$|</span> are shown. The crosses mark the positions of the lensing galaxies, and the triangles the positions of the sources in the source plane. The flux distributions of a lensed circular extended (S\u00e9rsic profile) source are shown. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/m_stu621fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&amp;Signature=MLXEyr~gt~2N9ONLZA8RE6aHe4Z4jxbCFXo2iQyzgus4hs7N1ZlxZhZ6QMUUN0hlynFmjmv4sWv4-cHfIo3lmJjG2ak3-RLsSJASZN7PJWOPMlVuDgRj1QzECXrigk-E2Vy25l~qJPX41mKgdiGUyNHiL8xRQJKAf7dirdif2jDm-UeW9y9uopHyvnSVGLhDJY4LO~mpJbudcSYG8DeOqmrCSxM-XXv2-tSVOD6KacRikykwtE9E5qjtljklKWLUNxYqf~BH6Ol3-jxpXfec0iDGiIWq6NjNbeRO1m6aVH4h4eAEArUmsUO0DA6j063cgb5y09GZk8MGVwqu0mhhRQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass models for SDSS J1405+0959. The crosses mark the positions of the lensing galaxies, and the triangles the positions of the sources in the source plane. The flux distributions of a lensed circular extended (S\u00e9rsic profile) source are shown. (The colour versions of this figure is available in the online.)\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92031888/stu621fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92031888\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/3/10.1093_mnras_stu1621/1/stu621fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467507&Signature=jQ5h1YGobtRaOu~aPJfS25DatdBLtWgXrH8-1myrizxY6EueloVO1vg7l-eceU-MTb0AtYQoW5poLYou~jvpY-9mmHDKjTBWKLnMp4ymXfcE7zTcxuIH3fzd1QcOYkc0hWLqYFcJB2x3N8~SpJdaq3WOtROkbLKpN9KTsQazvjhlQTcu-eYY5hTDkWqlGLyZL3tCs3x5kb6zofGvXxmGYp8fxwxvRxL~QECJBq45I5fcgPnAKJ2PiNSVwZgkQylS6jjvY5Kjlg5ZWC6q6gMjCHvMPKyaWbRTUAZk~Tj83YUEU-uviY-MWpnYdOqLjhR9FZIT2qJZGkhNoGxqr~D1vw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92031888&ar=1063465&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu621fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass models for SDSS J1405+0959. The orientation corresponds to that in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Critical lines <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {({\\rm blue})}$|</span> and caustics <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathit {({\\rm red})}$|</span> are shown. The crosses mark the positions of the lensing galaxies, and the triangles the positions of the sources in the source plane. The flux distributions of a lensed circular extended (S\u00e9rsic profile) source are shown. For each model, the first (second) line on the third and fourth columns refers to the parameters of G1 (G2); also, the first (second) line on the sixth and eighth columns refers to AB (AC) and <em>F</em><sub>B</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>A</sub> (<em>F</em><sub>C</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>A</sub>), respectively. The position angle is positive from north towards east. Values inside square brackets are constrained with a Gaussian prior given by the observed uncertainties. Unless otherwise specified, all models have (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/\u03bd = 0/0). \u03c3 represents the velocity dispersion of the singular isothermal mass model, \u03b8<sub>E</sub> is the Einstein radius, <em>e</em> is the ellipticity, \u0394<em>t</em> is the time delay and \u03bc represents the total magnification factor; \u03b4 and \u03b3<sup>\u2032</sup> represent the third-order perturbation to the potential and the logarithmic density slope, respectively. The error bars were determined using the Markov chain Monte Carlo method implemented in <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span>, where multiple chains were checked for convergence based on the method described in Gelman et al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>). External convergence from the environment is not considered in the models.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92031889\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl7\" data-id=\"tbl7\"><span class=\"label\">Table 7.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing models.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Model<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Images<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3, \u03b8<sub>E</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>e</em>, \u03b8<sub>e</sub> (deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b3, \u03b8<sub>\u03b3</sub> (deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394<em>t</em> (d)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03bc<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Flux ratio<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1.
